etymologies: early 17th century: from Latin inclusio(n-), from includere ‘shut in’

definitions: the action or state of including or of being included within a group or structure

examples.text: federal legislation now mandates the inclusion of students who are English language learners

shortDefinitions: action or state of including or of being included within group or structure

definitions: a person or thing that is included within a larger group or structure

examples.text: the exhibition features such inclusions as the study of the little girl

shortDefinitions: person or thing that is included within whole

definitions: the practice or policy of providing equal access to opportunities and resources for people who might otherwise be excluded or marginalized, such as those who have physical or mental disabilities and members of other minority groups

examples.text: we value and promote diversity and inclusion in every aspect of our business

shortDefinitions: practice of providing equal access to opportunities

definitions: a body or particle recognizably distinct from the substance in which it is embedded.
shortDefinitions: body or particle of distinct composition embedded in rock
